alert.note: Alert for Lincoln (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 07 at 1:46PM MDT until further notice by NWS Riverton
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Wyoming... Bear River affecting Lincoln County. .Warm temperatures have melted valley and mountain snowpack and increased river flows. Additional rainfall is forecast to impact this area Wednesday and Thursday, which may raise water levels to near major flood stage by the end of the week. There is even a possibility of reaching near record levels. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast due to the combination of snowmelt and additional forecast rainfall during the middle of next week. * WHERE...Bear River below Pixley Dam. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Flood stage. Minor agricultural flooding especially along left bank. At 9.5 feet, Agricultural flooding increases and becomes more widespread along both banks. Standing water on road to gagehouse. At 10.5 feet, Major widespread agricultural flooding. Road to gagehouse is under water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:15 PM MDT Sunday the stage was 8.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:15 PM MDT Sunday was 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain near 9 ft through the start of the week. There is a possibility for further rises to occur during the middle of next week. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.2 feet on 03/23/2017. && Fld Observed Forecasts (12 pm MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Mon Tue Wed Bear River below PixleyDam 8.5 8.7 Sun 1 pm MDT 8.5 8.8 9.6 &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
